data.title: TWiT Revision: The Numbers Behind Laporte's Podcast Network
data.meta_description: Master podcaster Leo Laporte’s TWiT is probably one of my favorite weekly content breaks across all platforms (broadcast, newspapers, Internet, etc.), so last week’s report regarding Revision3’s numbers versus TWiT’s hurt to post, but it had to be done. Since then, Laporte took the time to respond, so it seems only fair to allow him […]
data.text:
Master podcaster Leo Laporte’s TWiT is probably one of my favorite weekly content breaks across all platforms (broadcast, newspapers, Internet, etc.), so last week’s report regarding Revision3’s numbers versus TWiT’s hurt to post, but it had to be done.

Since then, Laporte took the time to respond, so it seems only fair to allow him to give his side of the story (with my own comments in brackets, of course). Laporte commented:

“Do you really think Compete has a clue as to either my numbers or Revision3's? [Answer: Yes] Do you know ANYONE who uses the Compete toolbar? [Answer: Yes]* They have even less credibility than Alexa numbers. Furthermore, that's a "measurement" of the twit.tv page vs. revision3.com. What do either have to do with podcast listenership? [Answer: Our report compared popularity, not listenership. Traffic is a significant indicator of popularity.] __According the very conservative Podtrac.com numbers (which count only unique US IP addresses) we're doing well over 2 million downloads a month. __Our bandwidth providers deliver more than two terabytes per day of content. I don't know if that beats Revision3, but I'm very happy with those numbers.”*

As far as I know, new Revision3 CEO Jim Louderback is still on vacation, so we may have to wait for similar download disclosure from Revision3. As for Laporte, his traffic might not be on par with Revision3’s, but the quality and consistency of his shows are certainly better, so he has every reason to believe that a well funded suitor will probably come knocking sooner rather than later. At that point, I imagine he’ll have to rethink that “not for sale” declaration.

Photo: decjr

The Architect of Russia’s Google Is Back

Yandex cofounder Arkady Volozh fought off sanctions and kicked anti-war squatters out of his Amsterdam townhouse. Now he is ready to reveal his new AI company in the Netherlands. But can Europe forget his past?

How IT Departments Scrambled to Address the CrowdStrike Chaos

System administrators and their teams sprang into action last Friday and worked tirelessly to get their companies back online amid one of the worst digital blackouts ever.

We Asked AI to Take Us On a Tour of Our Cities. It Was Chaos

We had a specialty chatbot to curate perfect days out in London and New York for under $100 each. We're still recovering from our journeys.

Bitcoin Bros Go Wild for Donald Trump

At Bitcoin 2024 conference in Nashville, Trump is finally telling crypto enthusiasts what they want to hear.

You Won’t Believe What Car Headlights Have in Store

New technology and a drive toward electrified powertrains have converged to create a flashy new car-lighting landscape. What comes next could be an international light language.

Tiny Texas Village Seeks Billion-Dollar Bitcoin Miner to Pave Potholes, Scare Dogs Away

In a roundabout bid to win public opinion (and a juicy tax abatement,) Riot Platforms is preparing for its prized bitcoin mine to be annexed by a minuscule village in rural Texas.

Google DeepMind’s Game-Playing AI Tackles a Chatbot Blind Spot

Google’s new advance combines a large language model with a self-learning AI. The technique could address some shortcomings with AI—although there’s a catch.

Craig Wright Faces Perjury Investigation Over Claims He Created Bitcoin

By order of a UK judge, Craig Wright can no longer claim he is the creator of bitcoin and now faces the prospect of criminal charges.
